overview:
This class allows you interact with Cloud Spanner.

First, install @google-cloud/spanner with npm:

$ npm install --save @google-cloud/spanner

If you are running your app on Google Compute Engine, you won't need to worry about supplying connection configuration options to @google-cloud/spannerâ€” we figure that out for you.

However, if you're running your app elsewhere, you will need to provide project details to authenticate API requests.

Google Cloud Platform

var spanner = require('@google-cloud/spanner')();

Elsewhere

var spanner = require('@google-cloud/spanner')({ projectId: 'grape-spaceship-123', keyFilename: '/path/to/keyfile.json' });

The full set of options which can be passed to @google-cloud/spanner are outlined in our Authentication guide.

params.name: database
params.description: Required. The database in which the new session is created.

methods.name: Session
methods.description: A session in the Cloud Spanner API.

params.name: name
params.description: Required. The name of the session.

params.name: name
params.description: Required. The name of the session to retrieve.

params.name: name
params.description: Required. The name of the session to delete.

params.name: session
params.description: Required. The session in which the SQL query should be performed.

params.name: transaction
params.description:
The transaction to use. If none is provided, the default is a temporary read-only transaction with strong concurrency.

This object should have the same structure as TransactionSelector

params.name: sql
params.description: Required. The SQL query string.

params.name: params
params.description:
The SQL query string can contain parameter placeholders. A parameter placeholder consists of '@' followed by the parameter name. Parameter names consist of any combination of letters, numbers, and underscores.

Parameters can appear anywhere that a literal value is expected. The same parameter name can be used more than once, for example: "WHERE id > @msg_id AND id < @msg_id + 100"

It is an error to execute an SQL query with unbound parameters.

Parameter values are specified using params, which is a JSON object whose keys are parameter names, and whose values are the corresponding parameter values.

This object should have the same structure as google.protobuf.Struct

params.name: paramTypes
params.description:
It is not always possible for Cloud Spanner to infer the right SQL type from a JSON value. For example, values of type BYTES and values of type STRING both appear in {@link params} as JSON strings.

In these cases, param_types can be used to specify the exact SQL type for some or all of the SQL query parameters. See the definition of {@link Type} for more information about SQL types.

params.name: resumeToken
params.description: If this request is resuming a previously interrupted SQL query execution, resume_token should be copied from the last {@link PartialResultSet} yielded before the interruption. Doing this enables the new SQL query execution to resume where the last one left off. The rest of the request parameters must exactly match the request that yielded this token.

params.name: queryMode
params.description:
Used to control the amount of debugging information returned in {@link ResultSetStats}.

The number should be among the values of QueryMode

methods.name: QueryMode
methods.description: Mode in which the query must be processed.

params.name: session
params.description: Required. The session in which the read should be performed.

params.name: transaction
params.description:
The transaction to use. If none is provided, the default is a temporary read-only transaction with strong concurrency.

This object should have the same structure as TransactionSelector

params.name: table
params.description: Required. The name of the table in the database to be read.

params.name: index
params.description: If non-empty, the name of an index on {@link table}. This index is used instead of the table primary key when interpreting {@link key_set} and sorting result rows. See {@link key_set} for further information.

params.name: columns
params.description: The columns of {@link table} to be returned for each row matching this request.

params.name: keySet
params.description:
Required. key_set identifies the rows to be yielded. key_set names the primary keys of the rows in {@link table} to be yielded, unless {@link index} is present. If {@link index} is present, then {@link key_set} instead names index keys in {@link index}.

Rows are yielded in table primary key order (if {@link index} is empty) or index key order (if {@link index} is non-empty).

It is not an error for the key_set to name rows that do not exist in the database. Read yields nothing for nonexistent rows.

This object should have the same structure as KeySet

params.name: limit
params.description: If greater than zero, only the first limit rows are yielded. If limit is zero, the default is no limit.

params.name: resumeToken
params.description: If this request is resuming a previously interrupted read, resume_token should be copied from the last {@link PartialResultSet} yielded before the interruption. Doing this enables the new read to resume where the last read left off. The rest of the request parameters must exactly match the request that yielded this token.

params.name: session
params.description: Required. The session in which the transaction runs.

params.name: options
params.description:
Required. Options for the new transaction.

This object should have the same structure as TransactionOptions

params.name: session
params.description: Required. The session in which the transaction to be committed is running.

params.name: transactionId
params.description: Commit a previously-started transaction.

params.name: singleUseTransaction
params.description:
Execute mutations in a temporary transaction. Note that unlike commit of a previously-started transaction, commit with a temporary transaction is non-idempotent. That is, if the CommitRequest is sent to Cloud Spanner more than once (for instance, due to retries in the application, or in the transport library), it is possible that the mutations are executed more than once. If this is undesirable, use {@link BeginTransaction} and {@link Commit} instead.

This object should have the same structure as TransactionOptions

params.name: mutations
params.description:
The mutations to be executed when this transaction commits. All mutations are applied atomically, in the order they appear in this list.

This object should have the same structure as Mutation

params.name: commitTimestamp
params.description:
The Cloud Spanner timestamp at which the transaction committed.

This object should have the same structure as google.protobuf.Timestamp

params.name: session
params.description: Required. The session in which the transaction to roll back is running.

params.name: transactionId
params.description: Required. The transaction to roll back.
